question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure that the code you generate can be executed for display. Summarize the subdivisions of the automotive chip industry and generate HTML code.

checklist.title: Is the automotive chip industry subdivision analysis comprehensive?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the content covers major automotive chip categories (e.g., MCU, SoC, ADAS processors, power management ICs, sensors). Check if the analysis includes key applications, technological trends, and market positioning of different chip types. Score 0 if only basic definitions are provided, 5 if common subdivisions are listed but lack depth, and 10 if comprehensive coverage with technical specifications and market contexts is included.

checklist.title: Does the HTML structure properly organize the industry subdivision content?
checklist.description: Review if the HTML structure uses appropriate semantic elements (e.g., section, article, header) to organize the content hierarchically. Check if the document structure reflects the logical relationship between different chip categories and their applications. Deduct 5 points if the HTML lacks proper sectioning elements, 3 points if heading levels (h1-h6) are improperly nested, and 2 points if there's no clear content organization. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the visualization include appropriate data representation?
checklist.description: Assess if the code implements visual elements (charts, diagrams, or tables) to represent market share, technical comparisons, or industry relationships. Evaluate if the chosen visualization methods effectively communicate complex chip industry information. Deduct 5 points if no visualization is included, 3 points if visualizations are present but don't add meaningful insight, and 2 points if the visualizations contain inaccurate data. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the implementation responsive and cross-browser compatible?
checklist.description: Check if the HTML code includes responsive design principles (media queries, flexible layouts, viewport meta tags) to ensure the content displays correctly across different screen sizes. Verify CSS prefixing or feature detection for cross-browser compatibility. Deduct 5 points if responsive design is absent, 3 points if it's partially implemented but breaks at certain viewports, and 2 points if browser-specific issues aren't addressed. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as missing data, image loading failures, script errors) and provides fallback options. Code with strong robustness should include error handling for API calls and graceful degradation. Give 10 points for comprehensive error handling, 5 points for basic error checks, and 0 points if no exception handling is implemented.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. Interactive drill-down capabilities for chip categories 2. Animated transitions between industry segments 3. Comparison tools for different chip specifications). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar visualization functions 2. Content elements unrelated to automotive chips 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., unnecessary animations, excessive DOM manipulation). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core information is obscured by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating content/presentation/behavior), code reusability, and maintainability. Deduct 5 points if inline styles are heavily used instead of external CSS; deduct 5 points if the code contains duplicated functionality or hardcoded values; deduct 5 points if JavaScript is not properly organized or lacks comments. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching (no more than 3 primary colors) 2) Proper layout spacing (element spacing follows the 8px multiple principle) 3) Professional font system (body font size ≥ 14px, line height over 1.5 times). Deduct 3 points for each crowded visual element, 5 points for a glaring color combination, and 5 points for chaotic text-image layout. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the dynamic effects conform to human perception characteristics: 1) Click feedback delay ≤ 100ms 2) Transition animation duration controlled between 300-500ms 3) Clear visual focus guidance. Deduct 5 points for each operation without feedback, 3 points for visual after-images during fast sliding, and 5 points for hard-to-find key function buttons. The full score is 10 points.
